I think any changes Obama introduces will be evolutionary rather than revolutionary - i.e. incremental changes. That is apparently how people who have worked with him in the past see his style. 
 
 Where taxes and the economy is concerned, he will continue the recent government trend of short term increase in debt in order to keep the US economy from sinking too low into a deeper recession or depression. I have already read that he will postpone his negation of the Bush's tax cuts (that would have increased taxes on the rich and upper middle class). However, I would not be surprised if he did carry through with this, along with his middle class tax cut, by 2010, as long as the economy stabilizes.
 
 Where his health plan is concerned, I suspect that the economic problems will force him to scale back or delay those plans as well. We will already need to get into enough extra debt to forestall major economic problems. Nevertheless, relatively speaking, his health care plan isn't all that expensive - factcheck.org estimates it at ~$50 to ~$100 billion, so I would not be surprised if he did try to push that (or a scaled-down program) through in the ~2010 timeframe or a bit later. Either way, I have 100% confidence that he will not try to push us into a system of purely socialized medicine - the great majority of us will keep the same style of private health insurance that we already do. However, I think he will try to introduce some new regulations to force private health insurers to accept people with pre-existing medical conditions.
 
 I think that those who were most elated around the world will find that he represents less of a change than they are hoping. Africans, Asians, Muslims and, of course, African Americans all think of him in a sense as one of them and I suspect that all of them expect that he will show some favoratism. That will simply not be the case. Obama will not be playing favorites or give special favors and this will be certain to disappoint many. Also, his support for expanding the war in Afghanistan, continued support for Israel (though I am not sure how one-sided that is), and his less beligerent but still strong rhetoric against Iran will all be exagerated to the hilt by extremists, who might succeed in convincing the local populations that he is just like previous presidents. Be that as it may, I think that, despite a dying down of the world's initial euphoria, they will be sufficiently sattisfied as long as he makes positive changes and avoids the bullying, unilateral, and ideologic style of the Bush administration.
 
 Where internal politics is concerned, I don't think that the Democratically controlled congress will go too far left to the point of alienating the moderate swing voters. Of course, most of its actions will anger those on the Religious RIght, but those are lost votes anyway. Social issues will be supported - including abortion rights, stem cell research, gun control (though I highly doubt that it will go as far as total ban on guns). Gay marriage will not be pushed forward (except for fringe groups and lesser politicians), but civil unions might be supported. Liberal Supreme Court justices will retire, to be replaced by justices that seem fairly left-of-center. As for political rhethoric and partisanship, I'm not sure. Initial signs are good and, if the moderate part of the Republican party ends up winning the current identity war, the fairly peaceful near-term relationship could continue. However, if the far right wing wins the Republican identity war, then partisanship will recover full blast and we will see a lot of filibustering and exagerated rhetoric...
 
 On terrorism, the extremists are currently in a wait-and-see mode since most people in the Middle East are positive about Obama and they cannot make a strong case against him until they have something specific to criticize. They may get this in his stance on Afghanistan, continued rhetoric about Iran's nuclear weapon's program, and his general support for Israel - i.e. they will exagerate this out of all proportion. Then, it depends on how most of the Middle East reacts. Certainly, Obama's stance is more moderate than Bush's. Will this, along with his heritage, convince those in the Middle East that we are no longer the "great Satan" or will the extremists be able to convince them otherwise? I don't know. Either way, relations will improve compared to the Bush administration. 
 
 On energy, I think we will continue to be very dependent on foreign oil by the time he leaves office (2012 or 2016). I think he will make some efforts at funding alternative fuels and might push for natural gas, ethonol, hybrids, and other similar nearer term technologies. However, it will still be a couple of decades before we see alternative non-fossil fuels make significant (tens of percent) entrance into our energy consumption.

 I'll grant you that it is easier to make grand statements of benevolence of society for the poor if one is not paying for that benevolence. Nevertheless, views of society's responsibility toward helping those less fortunate through government help are not only coming from retired people, they represent significant numbers - often majorities - of the US population. My salary would probably be classified under upper-middle class and, though I would not be affected by the Obama tax raise since my salary is still significantly under $250k, I would still be willing to pay a couple of extra percent of taxes if it really meant that we could have a sound safety net for everyone. This view is partly out of a feeling of responsibility toward those who are worse off, but it is also partly out of selfish desire to know that that safety net is there if I ever need one. Our economy is not perfectly sound where many industries have massive layoffs, and one is always a mere car accident away from being helplessly incapacitated and needing long term support. I, along with many others, simply think that it makes for a safer and better society if there is a stronger sense of community responsibility and care than if we are more in a dog-eat-dog world.
 
 I realize that many of our differences may mainly be in the degree to which this is practiced. For example, most Republicans I know (mostly moderates) are supportive of some sort of Social Security and Medicare - few would get rid of them outright. Most agree that it is right for the state to support the incapacitated. I think both Republicans and Democrats are hesitant in funding comfortable long term support for those who are neither incapacitated nor responsibly working or looking for work. However, I often get the impression that Republicans overestimate how many poor people are irresponsible while Democrats might underestimate that number. I suspect that the truth lies somewhere in between. However, even where the irresponsible poor are concerns, I personally still feel a sense of responsibility in giving them a minimal safety net - homeless shelters and food banks plus coverage under an Obama type subsidized health care program (note: since most of us would keep our current health care, I do not call his program socialist).

 Now, unlike most people, I do not feel a Pavlovian shudder of horror at the mention of the word "dictator." Dictatorial power is desirable and necessary in moments of emergency. One of the positive features of the Roman Republic was the office of Dictator, lasting no longer than six months. (The Roman Republic was doomed once they permitted the office to last a longer time, and then become perpetual)
 
 Franklin Roosevelt had many of the powers of a dictator, those powers were certainly necessary, and yet the United States did not reel and collapse into a state of irremediable, catastrophic horror because of them.
 
 Obama will be the source of all largess; he will be our dictator. In many ways, the future of the United States will be in his hands, and perhaps even its ultimate destiny. Whether his power will be positive or negative will in large part depend on how the people of America, high and low, react to that power: whether they will be prudent, intelligent and public spirited. I am not sanguine, but neither am I despairing.
 
 Obama will be surrounded by a storm of expectations; he will be like the captain of a sailing ship. For himself and the ship to survive, he must know these winds, know how to steer, when to raise and lower sails, how to tack, and how to handle the crew. 
 
 Above all, the fate of the ship, and of all of us, depends on the destination to which we are headed.

 As I said earlier, World War II ended the Great Depression. WWII ended the depression because of massive government spending. In 1940, government spending amounted to 9.34% of U.S. gross domestic product. By 1943, government spending had soared to 46.6% of U.S. gross domestic product. By 1945, military spending represented 89% of all federal spending. The reason government spending under the New Deal did not end the Great Depression was because there wasn't enough of it.
 
 War production made the U.S. government the chief consumer of goods produced. The U.S. did indeed supply significant amounts of arms to other nations, but much of this weaponry other nations did not pay for, or they paid for it at sharply discounted rates over a long period of time. Britain. the Soviet Union, France, and China were supplied with arms essentially for free through Lend-Lease, which was paid for by the United States government. And before Lend-Lease, of course, there was the cash and carry law, which severely limited arms sales to belligerant powers. 
 
 It was direct government spending that jump started the economy during World War II. The government spent money to fund the war, which created jobs, at the same time that the draft and the needs of the war created a labor shortage. The government thus became the nation's biggest consumer. It was the inability of individuals, either at home or abroad, to consume the goods produced by industry that kept the nation in depression. The New Deal spending programs were a step in the right direction, and each time the government spent more, the economy went up. When the government reduced spending and tried to balance the budget, the economy went down, notably in the Roosevelt recession of 1937. But overall government spending during the New Deal did not come close to the spending during the war. 
 
 WWII showed that Keynes was right, that government spending would pull an economy out of depression. The key, though, to the economy not sinking back into a depression was the re-conversion to a peacetime economy. The U.S. avoided a return to depression partly through the continuation of military spending, with the choice not to demobilize completely and to keep U.S troops stationed around the world. The U.S. economy was also bolstered after the war by the high wages that were then being paid to newly unionized industrial workers, and by the American decision to rebuild the economies of trading partners abroad through the Marshall Plan and other efforts. Despite a brief economic downturn after the war, these factors enabled the economy to be prosperous and to grow in the post-WWII period. 
 
 So, in sum, my argument to you is that it was indeed massive government spending on the war that pulled the U.S. economy out of the depression. 
 
 As for the government spending during the Bush 43 years, this spending probably did help to keep the economy pumping along. But as we know from our studies of economics, capitalist economies tend to sink into recession or depression; the business cycle has not gone away. We see that now, again. 
 
 Keynes, for all his oddities, was correct in his analysis of the role of government spending in softening the business cycle. But Keynes argued for counter-cyclical government deficit spending, not for government deficit spending during times of boom. Keynes never argued that government could spend all the time and never pay for anything. The Bush 43 fallacy was that the government could engage in massive deficit spending on a war while simultaneously cutting taxes and managing, somehow, to come out even. We will have to pay for our deficit spending. That is most certainly true.

 In 1946, federal government spending dropped by 40.4% from the previous year. The gross domestic product dropped by 0.36%, which is not much. The following year, 1947, federal government spending dropped by another 37.5%. That year the gross domestic product increased by 9%. In 1948, federal government spending dropped by 13.7%, and the gross domestic product increased by 9.3%. As we see from these figures, the decrease in federal spending after World War II did not produce a dramatic economic decline. The private sector successfully kicked in as a result of the demand that had been produced by war spending. The pent up demand of people having new money and having few consumer goods to buy during the war led to an increase in consumption immediately after the war. The Keynesian model worked; the massive federal government spending on the war successfully jump-started the economy and triggered renewed demand, which led to prosperity in the private sector after the war.

Let's look at federal spending from World War II until the current economic crisis. 
 
 Federal spending as a percentage of GDP was highest during World War II, in 1943 and 1944. In those years, federal government spending was 44.6% of GDP. 
 
 After the war, federal spending as a percentage of GDP went down. In 1948, federal spending dropped to 11.6% of GDP. During the Korean War, federal spending went up. In 1953, federal spending was 20.4% of GDP. It dropped in 1954 to 18.8% of GDP. In 1957, federal spending was down to 17% of GDP. 
 
 From 1958 through the 1960s, federal spending as a percentage of GDP went up and down. In 1965, federal spending was 17.2% of GDP. In 1968, at the peak of the Vietnam War, federal spending surged to 20.5% of GDP. By 1973, federal spending was back down to 18.7% of GDP.
 
 During the Reagan Presidency, in the years from 1981 through 1988, federal spending as a percentage of GDP was above 20%. Federal spending as a percentage of GDP was 22.2% in 1981 and reached a post-World War II high of 23.5% in 1983. Federal spending as a percentage of GDP dropped steadily from 1992 until 2000, during the Presidency of Bill Clinton. Federal spending as a percentage of GDP was down to 18.4% by the year 2000, the last year of the Clinton Presidency. 
 
 So, in sum, federal government spending as a percentage of GDP has gone up and down since World War II. During the years of the Reagan Presidency, federal spending as a percentage of GDP went up, while during the Clinton Presidency, federal spending as a percentage of GDP went down.

In 1946, federal government spending dropped by 40.4% from the previous year. The gross domestic product dropped by 0.36%, which is not much. The following year, 1947, federal government spending dropped by another 37.5%. That year the gross domestic product increased by 9%. In 1948, federal government spending dropped by 13.7%, and the gross domestic product increased by 9.3%.
 Gov't consumption went up in 1948 but yeah, it wasn't a huge recession.

Conclusion does not follow. Demand existed because you werent' allowed to buy anything for years and most of the worlds economy was rubble. 
 
 The circumstances are too different to make such a simplistic conclusion. 
 
 
The pent up demand of people having new money and having few consumer goods to buy during the war led to an increase in consumption immediately after the war. The Keynesian model worked; the massive federal government spending on the war successfully jump-started the economy and triggered renewed demand, which led to prosperity in the private sector after the war.
Again this is a misrepresentation of the Keynesian model. Keynes says (and this is an overly simplified explanation so no flaming) that demand will increase when people have more money which is provided by deficit spending of the government. The other side is more along the lines of a lack of supply causes demand (again a terrible way to put it but I'm keeping it short). In any event, WWII caused a few things to happen. One was government spending which no one doubts causes the economy to grow. The doubt comes in where you think it triggers other growth when the spending stops. The second event in WWII was that the supply of goods did not exist for consumers. So if we were to believe Keynes than an increase in income would prove helpful. If I recall correctly income between 1947 and 1949 did increase by a large amount. BUT it increased more around 1939-1941 (and the period around there). This did not keep any lasting effect...in fact, unemployment increased. Seems to me the trigger was not so much the spending but the lack of supply which got the economy going.

Let's look at federal spending from World War II until the current economic crisis. 
 
 Federal spending as a percentage of GDP was highest during World War II, in 1943 and 1944. In those years, federal government spending was 44.6% of GDP. 
 
 After the war, federal spending as a percentage of GDP went down. In 1948, federal spending dropped to 11.6% of GDP. During the Korean War, federal spending went up. In 1953, federal spending was 20.4% of GDP. It dropped in 1954 to 18.8% of GDP. In 1957, federal spending was down to 17% of GDP. 
 
 From 1958 through the 1960s, federal spending as a percentage of GDP went up and down. In 1965, federal spending was 17.2% of GDP. In 1968, at the peak of the Vietnam War, federal spending surged to 20.5% of GDP. By 1973, federal spending was back down to 18.7% of GDP.
 
 During the Reagan Presidency, in the years from 1981 through 1988, federal spending as a percentage of GDP was above 20%. Federal spending as a percentage of GDP was 22.2% in 1981 and reached a post-World War II high of 23.5% in 1983. Federal spending as a percentage of GDP dropped steadily from 1992 until 2000, during the Presidency of Bill Clinton. Federal spending as a percentage of GDP was down to 18.4% by the year 2000, the last year of the Clinton Presidency. 
 
 So, in sum, federal government spending as a percentage of GDP has gone up and down since World War II. During the years of the Reagan Presidency, federal spending as a percentage of GDP went up, while during the Clinton Presidency, federal spending as a percentage of GDP went down.
